cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle's blind spot, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay where you are to avoid surprising the driver.
questions.answerB: Wave at the other driver to get their attention.
questions.answerC: Slow down until you are out of the blind spot.
questions.answerD: Pull over to the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you find yourself riding in a vehicle's blind spot, you should either speed up quickly or slow down and drop back to vacate the spot.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When securing a load, you should place the load:
questions.answerC: On a sissy bar.
questions.answerD: Only on one side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Secured loads should be low. Putting them too high up, such as on a sissy bar, can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance. Loads should be as evenly distributed as possible on each side of the motorcycle to avoid pulling the bike to one side.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerC: After at least an hour of riding.
questions.answerD: After more than 8 hours of riding.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on trips shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: If you borrow a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Don’t worry about checking the tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Expect it to handle the same as your own bike.
questions.answerC: The lender will make sure the brakes work so you don't have to.
questions.answerD: Give yourself an extra cushion of space when riding to allow more time to react.
questions.explanation: If you borrow a motorcycle, make all of the same pre-ride safety checks that you would make on your own motorcycle. You should ride cautiously when using an unfamiliar motorcycle and allow yourself extra space when stopping.

questions.question: To accommodate a passenger, you may have to:
questions.answerC: Adjust the brakes.
questions.answerD: Adjust the throttle.
questions.explanation: Because of the extra weight placed on a motorcycle by a passenger, you may need to adjust the motorcycle's shocks before carrying a passenger. Because the motorcycle will sit at a different angle, you should also adjust the headlight and mirrors to compensate for the additional weight.

questions.question: Reflective material on your helmet:
questions.answerC: Should only be used at night.
questions.answerD: Does not help you to be seen.
questions.explanation: Reflective material on a vest or on the sides of your helmet can make you more visible to other drivers and should be used both day and night.

questions.question: In New Hampshire, a person who is age 21 or older with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is of legal drinking age with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and unsafe to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.explanation: The center of a lane can be especially hazardous when wet. When it begins to rain, avoid the center of the road by riding in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track is often the best option.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerC: Only to be used if the rear brake fails.
questions.answerD: Not to be used regularly.
questions.explanation: The front brake is safe to use as long as it is used properly. The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake, providing at least three-fourths of the total stopping power.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: When braking where traction is reduced, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes more quickly than usual.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes more gently than usual.
questions.answerC: Not use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Not use the front brake.
questions.explanation: When slowing or stopping on a surface with reduced traction, you should use caution and apply the brakes more gently than usual.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other traffic?
questions.answerC: Parking lots
questions.answerD: Residential areas
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between your motorcycle and other traffic is at intersections. Be extra alert when riding somewhere where another vehicle may cross in front of your path of travel.

questions.question: Of the following, the colors that best allow riders to be seen are:
questions.answerC: Purple and gold.
questions.answerD: Black and white.
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to others, wearing clothing that is bright orange, red, yellow, or green is best.

questions.question: When entering a turn, a rider should:
questions.answerC: Move their shoulders to match the angle of the turn.
questions.answerD: Sit up as high as possible.
questions.explanation: Before entering a turn, a motorcyclist should reduce their speed by closing the throttle and, if necessary, applying both brakes.

questions.question: To adjust for added weight when riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Operate at a slower speed than usual.
questions.answerB: Maintain a shorter following distance that you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Operate at a faster speed than usual.
questions.answerD: Brake a little later than you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.explanation: The extra weight of a passenger means that your motorcycle will need more time than usual to speed up, slow down, and turn. To accommodate the added weight, you should reduce your speed; start slowing earlier than normal; increase your following distance; and seek out larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging with traffic.

questions.question: When looking through a turn to see where you are going, you should:
questions.answerC: Turn just your shoulders.
questions.answerD: Turn your entire body.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When going through a turn on a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your eyes focused close to the front of the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Look through the turn to where you want to go.
questions.answerC: Turn your entire body to see through the turn.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed before the turn.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: The gear shift lever is located:
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest.
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest.
questions.answerC: Behind the left footrest.
questions.answerD: Behind the right footrest.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the left foot. To shift up to a higher gear, position your foot under the shift lever and lift. To downshift, press the shift lever down.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Move onto the shoulder to get out of their way.
questions.answerB: Speed up and put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerC: Ignore them.
questions.answerD: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.explanation: Usually, the best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to follow you at a faster speed.

questions.question: A skidding rear tire:
questions.answerB: Eliminates your ability to change direction.
questions.answerC: Will usually correct itself.
questions.answerD: Is only a concern if the front tire is also skidding.
questions.explanation: A skidding rear tire is a dangerous condition that can result in a violent crash and serious injury or death. Too much rear brake pressure can cause the rear wheel to lock. As soon as the rear wheel locks, your ability to change direction is lost. To regain control, the brake must be released.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake when slowing or stopping.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes when slowing or stopping.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when slowing or stopping, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be alert to oily areas, dirt, gravel, shaded areas, and bridges, as these surfaces are more likely to be slippery than others.

questions.question: Impairment from alcohol:
questions.answerB: Begins at about half of the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Occurs at the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Occurs only if you have had multiple drinks.
questions.explanation: As little as one drink can have a significant effect on the abilities that you need for safe riding. You can be impaired even if you are well below the legal blood alcohol limit. No amount of alcohol is safe to consume before riding.

questions.question: The center portion of a traffic lane is where:
questions.answerA: Debris and oil drippings from cars often collect.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle riders should always travel for safety.
questions.answerC: Most accidents happen.
questions.answerD: Drivers are least likely to see a motorcyclist.
questions.explanation: The centermost portion of a lane is where debris and oil drippings from cars often collect. Other hazards, such as utility hole covers, can also be found in the centermost portion of the lane.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars to your right when there is no oncoming traffic to your left, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay toward the right side of your lane.
questions.answerB: Stay toward the left side of your lane.
questions.answerC: Look to your left frequently.
questions.answerD: Use your rearview mirrors more frequently than usual.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is generally best to stay on the side of your lane that is not directly next to the cars. This will help to protect you from potential hazards like car doors being opened or people stepping out from between the cars. If there is traffic coming from the opposite direction, it is a good idea to stay in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When riding under ideal conditions, you should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as necessary.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Does not have any markings or tags.
questions.explanation: Any approved helmet will allow a rider to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding. Approved helmets will have labels and markings providing the manufacturer's name, relevant information and instructions, and information about the standards the helmet meets.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Equip and adjust your motorcycle to carry the passenger.
questions.answerB: Ride as you would without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Ensure that footrests are available for only you, the operator.
questions.answerD: Instruct the passenger after you begin your trip.
questions.explanation: You should transport a passenger only if your motorcycle is appropriately equipped and adjusted to do so. Among other things, your motorcycle should have separate footrests for the passenger and a seat that is large enough for more than one person to sit comfortably. You may need to adjust your headlight, tire pressure, and suspension to accommodate the extra weight of a passenger.

questions.question: When it starts raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Avoid riding down the center of a lane under wet conditions. Instead, ride in the tire tracks left by the cars ahead of you. The left tire track will often be best, but this can vary depending on traffic and other conditions.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, what could happen?
questions.answerA: Your motorcycle may lurch and the rear tire may skid.
questions.answerC: Your motorcycle may lurch and the front tire may skid.
questions.answerD: Your motorcycle may lurch and a warning light will go on.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, your motorcycle may lurch and the rear tire may skid, causing you to lose control of your motorcycle. Be sure that you are moving slowly enough before shifting into a lower gear.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to keep an eye on them without forcing the inexperienced rider to lead the group.

questions.question: The faster you drink:
questions.answerA: The more the alcohol will accumulate in your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerC: The more minimal the effects of the alcohol will be.
questions.answerD: The more likely you will be able to evade being pulled over.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the more alcohol will accumulate in your body. It is never safe to operate a motor vehicle after drinking alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: At a minimum, how often should a motorcycle's hydraulic fluid be checked?
questions.answerC: Once a year
questions.answerD: Before every ride
questions.explanation: Pre-ride motorcycle inspections are an important part of ensuring safe riding. Hydraulic fluids and coolants should be checked at least once a week.

questions.question: What is the primary psychoactive component in marijuana?
questions.answerC: MRT
questions.answerD: AAP
questions.explanation: The main psychoactive substance in marijuana is called tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC.

questions.question: Rain suits:
questions.answerC: Are not needed since motorcycles shouldn't be operated in the rain.
questions.answerD: Should tear easily.
questions.explanation: High-quality rain suits designed for motorcycle riding will resist tearing and ballooning when a rider travels at high speeds.

questions.question: When you park a motorcycle next to a curb, it should be:
questions.answerA: Parked at a 90-degree angle with the rear wheel touching the curb.
questions.answerB: Parked at a 45-degree angle with the front tire touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Parked like a car, with the front and rear wheels the same distance from the curb.
questions.answerD: Parked at the left edge of the parking space so approaching drivers can more easily see the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When parking a motorcycle next to a curb, you should create at a 90-degree angle with the curb by touching your rear wheel to the curb.

questions.question: When riding over rough surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handgrips loosely to allow for movement.
questions.answerB: Hold the handgrips firmly to maintain control.
questions.answerC: Use lots of throttle to help you get over the rough surface.
questions.answerD: Ride without a helmet as the helmet could become loose and cover your face.
questions.explanation: When riding over a rough surface, hold onto the handgrips firmly to ensure that you will maintain directional control over your motorcycle.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: The pass may be completed in a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: The rider may travel up to 10 mph over the speed limit to complete the pass.
questions.answerC: The pass must be started and completed within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: The pass must be completed on the shoulder, if one is present.
questions.explanation: Passing must be completed within the posted speed limits, and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: To swerve correctly, you should:
questions.answerC: Press the handle grip in the direction you plan to swerve.
questions.answerD: Press the handle grip in the direction opposite of where you plan to swerve.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Anywhere within the group.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride near the front of a group, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: Riding in cold weather for long periods of time could result in all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Severe chills.
questions.answerD: Hot flashes.
questions.explanation: Riding in cold weather for long periods of time can cause severe chill, fatigue, and even hypothermia. Be sure to wear proper clothing to protect you from the elements.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good color to wear to be seen?
questions.answerC: Brown
questions.answerD: Deep blue
questions.explanation: Orange, red, yellow, or green clothing can make you easier to see while riding a motorcycle. Wear brightly-colored clothing no matter what time of day you are riding.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing downward, it means the operator plans to slow down or stop.

questions.question: An experienced rider:
questions.answerA: Changes positions within their lane as conditions change.
questions.answerB: Stays in one portion of a lane at all times.
questions.answerC: Weaves within the lane to be more visible.
questions.answerD: Travels only on the oily portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Unlike drivers of larger vehicles, a motorcyclist has three lane position options in their travel lane. The rider should select whichever position is safest based on road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: To effectively provide protection for a motorcycle rider, pants should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Be made of a heavy material.
questions.answerC: Fit loosely enough that they flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Be short and expose some parts of the legs.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear pants that cover your entire legs and are made of leather or another sturdy synthetic material. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but not so snugly that it restricts your movement.

questions.question: Where is the engine cut-off switch usually located?
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The engine cut-off switch is generally located next to the right handgrip. It is important to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before starting out.

questions.question: What can help reduce the risk of a head or neck injury in the event of a crash?
questions.answerC: Wearing a helmet
questions.answerD: Not allowing a passenger on the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce the risk of head or neck injuries in the event of a crash.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator:
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: Brightly-colored helmets:
questions.answerA: May make it easier for the wearer to be seen.
questions.answerC: Don’t help to improve a rider's visibility.
questions.answerD: Are not permitted.
questions.explanation: Choosing a brightly-colored helmet is recommended. Not only will the helmet protect you in the case of a crash, but the bright color of the helmet will help other road users see you.

questions.question: Increase your following distance:
questions.answerB: If there are only a few vehicles on the roadway.
questions.answerC: If the sun is shining.
questions.answerD: If drivers are following the speed limit.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: When braking:
questions.answerA: Use only one brake if it is a non-emergency situation.
questions.answerB: Only use both brakes if you are riding on wet pavement.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes regardless of the circumstances.
questions.answerD: Use only the front brake.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Of the following, which clothing item will not reduce injuries in a crash?
questions.answerC: Shorts
questions.answerD: Full-fingered gloves
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of injury, riders should wear a helmet, eye protection, heavy shoes or boots, full-length pants, a jacket, and full-fingered gloves. Clothing should be made of durable materials to best protect the wearer.

questions.question: When riding, goggles:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face, but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Are not as effective at protecting your eyes as eyeglasses.
questions.answerD: Are not effective in providing any protection.
questions.explanation: Goggles can provide protection for your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face. Eyeglasses are not an adequate substitute for either goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: A motorcyclist's cushion of space:
questions.answerB: Should vary according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not necessary in most situations.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided to keep traffic moving safely.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: The best lane position is:
questions.answerA: The one that lets you travel the fastest.
questions.answerB: The one that allows you to draft off of other vehicles.
questions.answerC: The one that allows you be seen by other motorists.
questions.answerD: The one that places you in other vehicles’ blind spots.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: A motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerB: Can tip over if making a turn too fast.
questions.answerC: Is designed to take corners at any speed.
questions.answerD: Should not be used for loading items.
questions.explanation: Even with three wheels on the ground, a sidecar can tip over if it is being turned too sharply or is moving too fast for a corner.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Accelerate before turning.
questions.explanation: When approaching a potentially dangerous area, such as an intersection, you should cover the clutch lever and both brakes in order to reduce the amount of time you will need to react to any hazards.

questions.question: If a friend has had too much to drink and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take roads that are not crowded.
questions.answerC: Not get involved.
questions.answerD: Take their keys.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding, including taking their keys, if necessary. Arrange an alternative way for them to get home.

questions.question: Can clothing help prevent injuries in the event of a crash?
questions.answerA: No, clothing is not really for protection.
questions.answerB: No, clothing is more of a personal choice.
questions.answerC: Yes, but only if garments are very loose and flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Yes, if pants and a jacket cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.explanation: Appropriate clothing can reduce the risk of injury in a crash. Choose a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs, are made of sturdy material, and are snug enough that they do not flap in the wind.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: Always look through a turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head to look, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When passing parked vehicles, motorcycle riders should be especially cautious of:
questions.answerA: Motorists looking for a place to park.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Noise.
questions.explanation: When passing parked vehicles, use caution. You may encounter vehicles pulling away from the curb or leaving parking spaces.

questions.question: To be legal, a motorcycle must be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: A windshield wiper.
questions.answerD: A horn.
questions.explanation: In Minnesota, all motorcycles are required to be equipped with a rearview mirror, a horn, a muffler, one or two headlights, one red taillight, and at least one brake. If the motorcycle has a seat designed or suitable for use by a passenger, it must also have footrests or floorboards for the passenger.

questions.question: It is recommended that a motorcyclist:
questions.answerC: Change power suddenly in a turn.
questions.answerD: Ride the brake throughout the turn.
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you change gears prior to entering a turn.

questions.question: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, how many are caused by the driver failing to properly yield the right-of-way to the rider?
questions.answerC: Over 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 90 percent
questions.explanation: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, more than half are caused by the driver failing to properly yield right-of-way to the rider.

questions.question: The primary source of information about your motorcycle should come from:
questions.answerC: A library book about motorcycles.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle enthusiast.
questions.explanation: The owner's manual should be your primary source of information about your specific type of motorcycle. Be sure to read the manual before operating your motorcycle for the first time.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, you should:
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and gradually close the throttle.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: The best source of information for your motorcycle is:
questions.answerC: Someone who has a different type of motorcycle.
questions.answerD: A television show about motorcycle riding.
questions.explanation: To be sure you are familiar with the specific type of motorcycle that you are planning to ride, read the owner's manual before riding it for the first time. This is particularly important if you are riding a borrowed motorcycle.

questions.question: Swerving a motorcycle:
questions.answerC: Is a slow maneuver.
questions.answerD: Should be done to avoid a hazard on a slippery road.
questions.explanation: Swerving is a quick maneuver that requires a lot of traction in order to be safely executed. Making sudden moves, such as swerving, on slippery surfaces should be avoided.

questions.question: If your front wheel skids as a result of braking, you should:
questions.answerB: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks as a result of braking, you should release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.

questions.question: When riding at night, how should your following distance compare to your following distance during the day?
questions.answerA: You should allow a longer following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerB: You should allow a shorter following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerC: You should always maintain the same following distance regardless of the time of day.
questions.answerD: Following distance really doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: Distances are difficult to judge in the dark because visual cues (like shadows and light contrasts) can be missing or distorted. You should allow a longer following distance when riding at night than you do when riding during the day.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerB: After riding for a long time.
questions.answerC: Far from home.
questions.answerD: On short trips.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on short trips that are less than five miles long at speeds slower than 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: If a driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerC: Prevent them from passing.
questions.answerD: Move to one side of your lane to allow them to share the lane.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to keep tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered protective eye wear?
questions.answerC: Goggles
questions.answerD: A face shield
questions.explanation: Even if a motorcycle has a windscreen, riders are required to wear protective eyewear, such as appropriate glasses, goggles, or face shields. Contact lenses do not satisfy this requirement.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable as long as you stay under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Is safer on a motorcycle than in a car.
questions.answerC: Is acceptable as long as no vehicles are near you.
questions.answerD: Can cause you to end up in another lane or leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast is dangerous. If you cannot hold the turn, you may end up turning into another lane or even off of the road entirely. Use caution when taking a turn.

questions.question: What may help if you experience slippage of your drive chain?
questions.answerC: Using the throttle more
questions.answerD: Applying the rear brake
questions.explanation: If you experience chain slippage, tightening the chain may help. If tightening the chain does not reverse the problem, replace the chain before continuing to ride your motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding in a group, what does it mean when the lead rider raises their left arm and extends their index finger, as shown in the image?
questions.answerC: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerD: The group will pull off at the next exit.
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. A lead rider raising their left arm and extending their index finger means that the group of riders should move into a single-file formation.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle and trying to turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the grip in the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerB: Press the grip opposite of the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerC: Not hold the grip because it can be dangerous.
questions.answerD: Not lean the motorcycle as that can be unsafe.
questions.explanation: When traveling faster than a walking pace, your motorcycle will need to lean to turn. Pressing the grip in the direction you want to turn will cause you to lean in the appropriate direction

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: There is no need to do a head check if you use your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Mirrors provide a full view of the road around your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: You should turn your head and look over your shoulder.
questions.answerD: You can assume drivers will properly respond to your turn signal.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head and look over your shoulder to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight. Increasing your visibility by wearing bright colors and reflective materials is a good idea at all times.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a benefit of riding in a close group?
questions.answerA: It takes up minimal space on the highway.
questions.answerB: The group is easy to see.
questions.answerC: The group is unlikely to be split up.
questions.answerD: The riders will get to their destination more quickly in a close group than a group that is spread out.
questions.explanation: Riding in close ranks is recommended over riding in a group that is spread out because the group will take up less space on the road, be easier for others to see, and be less likely to get separated at traffic lights and during passes.

questions.question: When riding, the best protection for an operator is:
questions.answerA: A cushion of space between their vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerD: A good understanding of motorcycle laws.
questions.explanation: Your first and best protection against collisions with other vehicles is simply to keep your distance from them. The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you. Wearing proper gear is also important when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: When it is obvious that you are going to turn, you:
questions.answerA: Do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.answerB: Should still use a turn signal.
questions.answerC: Only need to use a turn signal if there are nearby pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Only need to use a turn signal if you are at a stop light.
questions.explanation: You must use proper turn signals every time you turn or change lanes, even if you think your intentions are obvious. Signals are always important, even if no one else seems to be around to see them. There may be other vehicles nearby that you can't see or haven't yet noticed.

questions.question: Why should a load be placed low on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: If a load is too high, it raises the center of gravity.
questions.answerB: If a load is too high, it may interfere with the turn signals.
questions.answerC: It may be difficult to see over a load that is placed too high.
questions.answerD: Others can't see your load if it is low.
questions.explanation: Placing a load too high on a motorcycle will raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and risk upsetting its balance.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should ride:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Wherever they are most comfortable.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should ride just behind the leader near the front of the group. This allows more experienced riders to keep an eye on them from the back of the group.

questions.question: Which formation is best for keeping the riders in a group close together?
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Riding at night:
questions.answerB: Is made safer by wearing reflective clothing.
questions.answerC: Is not safe because other drivers cannot see your turn signals.
questions.answerD: Should only be done in the city.
questions.explanation: You should wear reflective materials when riding at night to make yourself more visible to other road users.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble is dangerous and will only make your motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly (without trying to fight the wobble), gradually close the throttle to slow down, and move your weight as far forward and downward as possible. Pull off the road as soon as you can.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before.
questions.answerB: Not assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before and explain the process.
questions.answerC: Not let them ask questions.
questions.answerD: Not bother with explaining anything since they are only a passenger and not in control of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle passenger needs to understand how to ensure a safe ride ride for both themselves and the operator. An operator should never assume the passenger already knows what to do. Give a passenger complete instructions before every ride.

questions.question: To get the best possible protection, wear a helmet that:
questions.answerC: Is pretty loose.
questions.answerD: Does not have a chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: If hazards are on your left, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When hazards exist to your left, it is often best to ride in the right portion of the lane. Be prepared to adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield must:
questions.answerC: Not allow for eyeglasses to fit underneath.
questions.answerD: Restrict your vision to the sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: How often should a motorcycle operator check their mirrors?
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: More often than the amount time spent looking ahead
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you frequently check your mirrors to be aware of potential hazards behind you.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should:
questions.answerC: Be complicated to perform.
questions.answerD: Not be done before every ride.
questions.explanation: It is important to do a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take you only a few minutes.

questions.question: To increase your line of sight when preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Try to stand up on your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This will increase your line of sight and make you more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: A flat front tire is especially hazardous because:
questions.answerB: The front tire provides the power for the bike, so you will lose acceleration.
questions.answerC: The flat tire will shake the bike, making it hard to use the mirrors.
questions.answerD: You won’t be able to use the brake.
questions.explanation: A flat front tire is especially dangerous because it affects your ability to steer. If your front tire goes flat while you are riding, safely exit the road as quickly as possible.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: A simple way to make your motorcycle easier to see is to:
questions.answerA: Ride with a large flag attached to its frame.
questions.answerB: Ride with the headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: Wave at other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder whenever possible.
questions.explanation: You can make yourself easier to see by wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing. Ride with your headlight on at all times and use your turn signals and brake light appropriately.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Do not have blind spots because of their small size.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots, but they are so small they should not cause concern.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that should be routinely checked.
questions.answerD: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes. Head checks should be a regular part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: To control a motorcycle properly, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit so you can use your arms to steer, not to hold yourself up.
questions.answerB: Sit far enough back on the seat that you can keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Drag your feet on the ground.
questions.explanation: When riding, sit so you are able use your arms to control the motorcycle rather than to hold yourself up. Your arms should be slightly bent when you are holding the handle grips. To help maintain your balance, keep your knees against the gas tank and your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: When planning a long group ride, which of the following ideas should not be implemented?
questions.answerA: The lengths of travel segments should be based on the least experienced rider.
questions.answerB: Breaks should be minimized so the riders can get to their destination as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leaders.
questions.answerD: The group should maintain a staggered riding formation.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, the length of a route and the lengths of segments of travel should be based on the skill level of the least experienced rider. Groups of riders should take regular breaks to reduce fatigue. Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leader so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind. It is generally best to ride in a staggered formation.

questions.question: Riding at night is usually:
questions.answerA: Easier than riding during the day because you can more easily see the lights of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: More difficult than riding during the day because it is harder to see.
questions.answerC: Not allowed on highways.
questions.answerD: Less distracting than riding during the day.
questions.explanation: Riding safely at night is challenging because it is harder to see and be seen than it is during the day. The absence of normal shadows and light contrasts makes it harder to judge distances.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: The single most effective thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving an accident is:
questions.answerC: Ask others about how to ride more safely.
questions.answerD: Watch training videos.
questions.explanation: The single most important measure you can take to reduce your risk of injury or death in the event of an accident is to wear a helmet.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, it is important that all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerC: The helmet fits snugly.
questions.answerD: The helmet does not have any defects.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you have a helmet that will provide the best possible protection, you should choose one that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards. It should fit snugly all the way around and have no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: Maximum front-line braking is accomplished by:
questions.answerC: Using both brakes.
questions.answerD: Using the rear brake while downshifting.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by fully applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel. You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: A face shield should:
questions.answerA: Allow a clear view to both sides.
questions.answerB: Prevent air from passing through it.
questions.answerC: Be tight enough to prevent glasses from fitting underneath it.
questions.answerD: Should not fasten too tightly.
questions.explanation: To be effective, a face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The rear brake should be applied first.
questions.answerB: The front brake should be applied first.
questions.answerC: Both brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.answerD: Only one brake, front or rear, should be used.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow down or stop. Always apply the brakes simultaneously.

questions.question: When selecting footwear, you should choose:
questions.answerB: Shoes with long laces that cannot be tucked in.
questions.answerC: Shoes that cover your ankles.
questions.answerD: Shoes that are made from flimsy materials.
questions.explanation: When riding, wear boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be short so they don't catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so they can't catch onto the moving parts of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerB: Not be worn during the day
questions.answerC: Never be worn.
questions.answerD: Not be worn at night.
questions.explanation: Wear reflective materials to increase your visibility, especially when riding at night. Brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials will make you more visible to other road users.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as effectively as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects your entire face in a crash. Goggles protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used when you need to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be used only under slippery conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not as effective as the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Is safe to use, if used properly.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop. It is safe to use the front brake, which is more powerful than the rear brake, as long as you use it properly.

questions.question: Penalties for riding while impaired may include:
questions.answerC: Community service.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: If convicted of a DWI, you may face fines, license suspension, jail time, court costs, legal defense fees, an insurance rate increase, and community service. If you have been drinking, it is best to stay off your motorcycle.

questions.question: Normally, you should maintain a following distance of:
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should allow at least two seconds of distance between you and the vehicle ahead of you. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than ideal.

questions.question: Slippery surfaces can make it difficult to control a motorcycle. Which of the following would be considered a slippery surface?
questions.answerC: Dry pavement
questions.answerD: A parking lot
questions.explanation: Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be slippery surfaces. Motorcyclists should ride with extra caution when riding over slippery surfaces.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than you would normally.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you would normally.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerD: Not communicate with the passenger while riding.
questions.explanation: Because of a passenger's additional weight, a motorcycle will respond more slowly with a passenger on board than with just one occupant. With a passenger, you should travel a bit more slowly than you normally would, start slowing sooner than you normally would, and increase your following distance. Always warn your passenger of any special conditions ahead.

questions.question: When consumed together, the effects of alcohol and drugs:
questions.answerA: Can be more pronounced than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerB: Are less dangerous than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerC: Are usually minimal.
questions.answerD: Often balance out.
questions.explanation: Many drugs, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your ability to ride safely. Some medications become even more dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Be flexible about your lane position and adjust to changing conditions.
questions.answerB: Travel at a faster speed than usual to get to your destination more quickly.
questions.answerC: Always use your low beam headlight to see better.
questions.answerD: Decrease your following distance so you can be as close as possible to the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night. Be especially careful to employ safe riding strategies when riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: Hearing protection is:
questions.answerA: Not needed if you wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Needed in addition to a helmet.
questions.answerC: Only needed on windy days.
questions.answerD: Not needed if you are carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Exposure to engine and wind noise can damage your hearing, even if you are wearing a helmet. Hearing protection can guard against this while still allowing you to hear essential sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: If either tire goes flat while riding, you should:
questions.answerC: Gently apply the brake of the non-flat tire.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to exit the road more quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires goes flat while you are riding, you should ease off the throttle and maintain a straight course as you slow down. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat, if you are certain of which tire that is.

questions.question: In general, riders should:
questions.answerA: Pick one lane position and always use it.
questions.answerB: Change lane positions frequently to prevent monotony.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position that maximizes their space cushion.
questions.answerD: Never use the center lane position.
questions.explanation: Because road and traffic conditions are always changing, the safest lane position is also always changing. Choose the position that will maximize your space cushion and allow other drivers to see you most easily.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: What is the best lane position for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerA: The left position in the lane
questions.answerB: The center position in the lane
questions.answerC: The right position in the lane
questions.answerD: There is no single lane position that is best for all situations.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for your current riding conditions, allowing you to maintain an adequate space cushion and be visible to others.

questions.question: Do not change gears on railroad tracks because:
questions.answerC: Other drivers may not be expecting you to change gears.
questions.answerD: The uneven surface may make it more difficult to switch gears.
questions.explanation: It is best not to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks. There is a chance your motorcycle might stall while you are on the tracks.

questions.question: When riding at night you should:
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle in front of you to help see.
questions.answerD: Wear tinted glasses.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: When riding in curves, turning, or entering a highway, the best group formation is:
questions.answerC: Staggered.
questions.answerD: Passing.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is generally the best option when traveling in a group, riders should move into a single-file line through curves, through turns, and when entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When you are being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in any portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind, stay in the center portion of your lane. This will discourage the other driver from re-entering your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it is more difficult to see and judge distances in the dark than in daylight, you should maintain an expanded following distance of at least three seconds when riding at night. It may take you longer than usual to realize the vehicle in front of you has stopped and you may need additional time to slow or stop to avoid hitting the vehicle.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.answerD: Ride under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: In potential high-risk areas, such as near intersections, shopping areas, school zones, and construction zones, cover the clutch and both brakes to reduce the time you will need to react to potential hazards.

questions.question: To get the best protection, be sure that your helmet:
questions.answerC: Is inexpensive.
questions.answerD: Is in your favorite color.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a slippery surface?
questions.answerC: An ice patch
questions.answerD: Dry concrete
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: A passenger should lean with the operator through turns and curves. They should sit as far forward as possible, without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle, and hold onto passenger handholds or the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: If riding a three-wheel motorcycle in a group, you should travel in a:
questions.answerC: Single-file line.
questions.answerD: Row of pairs.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best for a group of two-wheeled motorcycles, three-wheeled motorcycles are too wide to allow this formation. A group of riders on three-wheeled motorcycles should travel in a single-file line.

questions.question: For passengers, a helmet:
questions.answerB: Is required for those under the age of 18.
questions.answerC: Is required, but only if the operator has not had their license at least two years.
questions.answerD: Is always required.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle operators and passengers under the age of 18, and riders of any age who are operating on a motorcycle permit, must wear approved helmets while riding. It is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets every time they ride.

questions.question: Braking in a turn is:
questions.answerA: Easier than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: More difficult than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Done safely by using the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Done safely by using the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: Braking in a turn is not as easy as braking on a straightaway. It is possible to use both brakes to brake in a turn, but the operator must know the proper technique and exercise great care.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way for a rider to increase their visibility?
questions.answerB: Using their headlight at all times
questions.answerC: Using their turn signals
questions.answerD: Waving at other drivers
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the bike as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto the operator.
questions.explanation: Passengers should sit directly behind the operator and lean as the operator leans. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator, holding onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: If you must ride over an obstacle, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed as much as possible.
questions.answerB: Lean the motorcycle to one side.
questions.answerC: Speed up, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on your seat and remove your feet from the footrests.
questions.explanation: If you are unable avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Keep your motorcycle straight up and down, if possible. Just before contact, roll off the throttle slightly to lighten the front end of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Clothing made of which type of material can offer the best protection to motorcyclists?
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Silk
questions.explanation: Leather garments can provide the greatest level of protection to motorcyclists. It is important to wear clothing that covers your legs and arms entirely when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: Several factors influence blood alcohol concentration (BAC). Which of the following does not play a role?
questions.answerC: Body weight
questions.answerD: Height
questions.explanation: There are several major factors that can affect a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC). A BAC is determined in part by the amount of alcohol someone has consumed, how fast they consumed the alcohol, and their body weight.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerB: You will be slowing down suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals do not work.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle's single brake light is not as noticeable as the two larger brake lights of a car or truck. It can be a good idea to flash your brake light to help others notice it, especially when you need to slow down more quickly than surrounding drivers may expect.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Release the brake until the rear tire regains traction, then re-apply the brake.
questions.answerB: Release the brake and only engage the front brake.
questions.answerC: Keep it locked until the motorcycle comes to a stop.
questions.answerD: Release the brake and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your rear wheel locks while braking, do not release the brake. Instead, keep it locked until you come to a full stop.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because they will distract you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided since other drivers will see you easily.
questions.answerD: Are only recommended in bad weather.
questions.explanation: For your safety, it is important to be aware of what's behind you. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal searching routine.

questions.question: In regards to drinking and riding, many penalties are:
questions.answerB: Up to a judge to decide.
questions.answerC: Not too harsh.
questions.answerD: Optional.
questions.explanation: Oregon law applies severe mandatory penalties for drinking and riding. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: You have been drinking alcohol. If you wait an hour for each drink before riding your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects from the drinking may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be okay as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, the body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, some alcohol may accumulate in the body even if a person consumes only one drink per hour. Their abilities and judgment can still be impaired.

questions.question: Which of the following is a poor reason to sound your horn?
questions.answerA: A driver in the lane next to you is too close to the vehicle ahead of them.
questions.answerB: A parked car has a person in the driver’s seat.
questions.answerC: You want people to look at your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: You are passing someone who is in the street.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to sound your horn before riding past a vehicle or pedestrian that may move into your lane. If you see a driver in an adjacent lane driving too closely to the vehicle ahead of them, you may assume that they want to pass and may cut in front of you to do so. If you see a person in the driver's seat of a parked car, or if you see a pedestrian or bicyclist in the street, it is a good idea to sound your horn as you pass.

questions.question: A windshield:
questions.answerA: Is a good substitute for a face shield.
questions.answerB: Does not completely protect your eyes from the wind.
questions.answerC: Is required on all motorcycles.
questions.answerD: Should be used on windy days.
questions.explanation: A windshield is not an adequate substitute for the protection offered by goggles or a face shield. Most windshields will not protect your eyes from the wind.

questions.question: How can a motorcycle operator discourage lane sharing by other drivers?
questions.answerA: By giving dirty looks to other drivers
questions.answerB: By riding in the center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: By riding in the left portion of the lane
questions.answerD: By riding in a zigzag pattern
questions.explanation: By riding in the center portion of your lane, you will ensure that there is not a large space on either side of your motorcycle. Minimizing those spaces can help deter drivers from trying to share the lane with you.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: Engine braking:
questions.answerB: Is slowing down by turning the engine off.
questions.answerC: Is slowing down by downshifting.
questions.answerD: Is not encouraged because of the damage it does to the engine.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should continually scan the road ahead for:
questions.answerC: Escape routes.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Scan the road ahead to remain alert to changing traffic conditions, hazardous road conditions, and escape routes. Be prepared to react to any changing conditions.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: Close to the back of the group.
questions.answerD: At the tail end of the group.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, less experienced riders should be positioned toward the front, just behind the leader. This ensures that they will not have to chase after the rest of the group. This positioning also allows them to be watched from behind by more experienced riders.

questions.question: When it comes to motorcycle safety, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume everything on your motorcycle will work properly.
questions.answerB: Conduct a pre-ride inspection before every ride.
questions.answerC: Conduct a pre-ride inspection each month.
questions.answerD: Conduct a pre-ride inspection twice a week.
questions.explanation: A small mechanical fault can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.answerD: 0.1 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is age 21 or older with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is illegal and dangerous to operate any motor vehicle while intoxicated.

questions.question: When crossing angled railroad tracks, it is usually safest to approach the tracks:
questions.answerA: By proceeding straight within your lane.
questions.answerC: At a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerD: At a fast speed.
questions.explanation: In general, it is safest to simply proceed straight in your lane when crossing angled railroad tracks. Turning to approach tracks at a right angle can be dangerous because it may send you traveling into another lane.

questions.question: Which of the following will best protect your eyes from wind?
questions.answerC: A windshield
questions.answerD: Goggles
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields will help protect your eyes from wind. Most windshields, as well as eyeglasses or sunglasses, will not.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can help protect your whole face in a crash. While goggles can protect your eyes, they won't protect the rest of your face. A windshield is not a substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders:
questions.answerA: Should wear hearing protection at all times to prevent hearing damage.
questions.answerB: Should only wear hearing protection during long rides.
questions.answerC: Should not wear hearing protection because it will muffle other noises, such as horns and sirens.
questions.answerD: Do not need to use hearing protection if they are using a helmet.
questions.explanation: Longterm exposure to wind and engine noise can cause permanent hearing damage, even if the rider is wearing a full-face helmet. Wearing ear plugs or other hearing protection can guard against damage while still allowing the wearer to hear important sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: ____ can remove alcohol and its effects from your body.
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.answerD: Fresh air
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is not drinking alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, fresh air, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a wobble on your motorcycle?
questions.answerC: Unsuitable accessories
questions.answerD: Uneven road
questions.explanation: Most wobbles can be traced to improper loading, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure. Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within a foot of the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Signal only when you feel like it.
questions.answerD: Stay alert and be prepared to act to avoid a crash.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: For a person to be allowed to ride as a passenger:
questions.answerA: They must be able to reach the footrests on both sides of the motorcycle while seated.
questions.answerB: They must hold a motorcycle license.
questions.answerC: They must be willing to operate the motorcycle if the operator becomes too tired.
questions.answerD: They must be older than 18 years old.
questions.explanation: A person may not ride as a passenger on a motorcycle unless they are able to reach the footrests on each side of the motorcycle while seated.

questions.question: To receive maximum protection, wear a helmet that is certified by the:
questions.answerC: Federal Transportation Network.
questions.answerD: National Association of Helmets.
